message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fetal position (transverse lie) is not conducive to vaginal birth, thus Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step in management. Oxytocin and normal vaginal birth may not succeed as the baby is not in the proper position for delivery. Lateral positioning of the mother or external cephalic version may be tried but a Cesarean section is typically the safest option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasonography result shows a transverse lie of the fetus which carries risks and is not conducive to safe vaginal birth. Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. Options A, B, and D are not appropriate management for a transverse lie.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fetal malpresentation is a transverse lie and is a contraindication for a vaginal birth. The recommended management is delivery by cesarean section. Administration of oxytocin or lateral positioning may not be effective in this situation. External cephalic version is not appropriate in cases of transverse lie.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis is transverse lie, which means the fetus is not in the correct position for a vaginal birth. Administration of oxytocin and normal vaginal birth is not appropriate in this case. Lateral positioning of the mother may help promote fetal rotation but is not guaranteed to be effective. External cephalic version may be attempted but carries risks and is not always successful. The most appropriate next step in this case is a cesarean section to ensure a safe delivery for both the mother and the baby.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasonography shows transverse lie, which is not a safe position for vaginal delivery. Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient to avoid risks of vaginal delivery in transverse lie position.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the fetal long axis is at a right angle compared to the long axis of the maternal uterus indicates a transverse lie, which makes normal vaginal birth not possible. Lateral positioning or administration of oxytocin may not solve the problem. External cephalic version is also not appropriate in this case. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is a Cesarean section.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fetal long axis being at a right angle compared to the long axis of the maternal uterus is a sign of transverse lie, which means the baby is laying sideways in the uterus. This position makes vaginal delivery unsafe, and therefore Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step in management. The other options should not be considered until the baby is in the correct position for delivery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound finding of the fetal long axis being at a right angle compared to the long axis of the maternal uterus suggests a transverse lie, which is not compatible with a vaginal delivery. Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. The other options are not appropriate for a transverse lie.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fetal position is transverse lie, which is a contraindication to a vaginal birth. Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step for the safe delivery of the infant. The other options are not appropriate for a transverse lie fetal position.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fetal position described suggests a transverse lie, which is a contraindication to vaginal delivery. Cesarean section is the most appropriate next step in management. Administration of oxytocin may increase the risk of fetal distress and external cephalic version is not appropriate in cases of transverse lie. Lateral positioning of the mother may help with fetal positioning but is not the most appropriate next step in management given the transverse lie.
